value: <l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">21</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">strong. The watermen of the <rs type="place" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#pla-bank" key="Bankside">Bankside</rs> lived on their fares.</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">The flag flew; the trumpets sounded; and the 
            <choice>
              <sic>audince</sic>
              <corr>audience</corr>
            </choice></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">paying their penny, their two pence or their six pence,</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">
            <choice>
              <sic>criwded</sic>
              <corr>crowded</corr>
            </choice> into the playhouse, and beheld in the light</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">of day noxmxmxmxmxmx <add hand="ms" place="above">[illeg.]</add> actors, richly dressed 
            <choice>
              <sic>accoring</sic>
              <corr>according</corr>
            </choice> to</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">one spectator in  the cast off robes of the 
            <choice>
              <sic>novbles</sic>
              <corr>nobles</corr>
            </choice>, sold by</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">their servants. in the taffetas and tinsels that 
            <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-phen" key="Henslowe, Philip"><choice>
              <sic>Hensloew</sic>
              <corr>Henslowe</corr>
            </choice></rs></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">in the satin doublets and hose laid thick with gold lace</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">that 
            <choice>
              <sic>Henslew</sic>
              <corr>Henslowe</corr>
            </choice> entered in his book. But; or 
            <choice>
              <sic>accorind</sic>
              <corr>according</corr>
            </choice> to th 
            <choice>
              <sic>on</sic>
              <corr>one</corr>
            </choice></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">spectator, dressed in the cast off robes of their servants. There was no scenery. The sun beat</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">or the rain 
            <choice>
              <sic>pour d</sic>
              <corr>poured</corr>
            </choice> on the common people standing in the yard.</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">
            <choice>
              <sic>A d</sic>
              <corr>And</corr>
            </choice> then the actor spoke:</l>

<quote xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" source="#" rend="inline">
            <l>Brother Cosroe, I find myself aggrieved,</l>
            <l>Yet insufficient to express the same;</l>
            <l>For it requires a great and 
              <choice>
                <sic>thunder ng</sic>
                <corr>thundering</corr>
              </choice> speech</l>
          </quote>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">At last the voice of a real man speaks. The play is</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">centred; concentrated. It has a lodging. The 
            <choice>
              <sic>wabdering</sic>
              <corr>wandering</corr>
            </choice> voices</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">xmxmxmxxx are concentrated; the</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">At last the wandering voices are collected. One man speaks</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">in his own person. The 
            <choice>
              <sic>wnadering</sic>
              <corr>wandering</corr>
            </choice> voices are collected<add place="inline" hand="ms">: [centred?]</add></l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">There is no abstraction any longer. All is visible, 
            <choice>
              <sic>tamgible</sic>
              <corr>tangible</corr>
            </choice></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">audible. The world takes shape behind him. Egypt and Libya</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">and 
            <choice>
              <sic>Perisa</sic>
              <corr>Persia</corr>
            </choice> and Greece unroll bxmxmxmxmmxx and armies and</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">Kings and 
              <choice>
                <sic>p ains</sic>
                <corr>plains</corr>
              </choice>. Kings and Emperors 
              <choice>
                <sic>strdie</sic>
                <corr>stride</corr>
              </choice> 
              <choice>
                <sic>fort </sic>
                <corr>forth</corr>
              </choice>,</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">palpable, and strident. They emerge like great moths,</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">xmxmxmx sxmxmxmx shaking their wings still creased and</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">damp in 
            <choice>
              <sic>ansurd</sic>
              <corr>absurd</corr>
            </choice> hyperboles.</l>
